channel.title: Science : NPR
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 NPR - For Personal Use Only

channel.itunes:summary: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast. http://www.npr.org/sections/science/

item.title: Dalia Mogahed: How Does Speaking Up Change Minds?
item.description: April 7, 2017 - After 9/11, Dalia Mogahed saw an increase in negative perceptions of Muslims in the media, so she made it her job to speak up for her faith and fight prejudice with better understanding.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 7, 2017 - After 9/11, Dalia Mogahed saw an increase in negative perceptions of Muslims in the media, so she made it her job to speak up for her faith and fight prejudice with better understanding. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/07/522859280/dalia-mogahed-how-does-speaking-up-change-minds

item.title: Adam Galinksy: What Drives Us To Speak Up?
item.description: April 7, 2017 - Social psychologist Adam Galinsky studies why it's so daunting to speak up — and what can help. He says the most powerful factor that compels us to take that risk is "moral conviction."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 7, 2017 - Social psychologist Adam Galinsky studies why it's so daunting to speak up — and what can help. He says the most powerful factor that compels us to take that risk is "moral conviction." http://www.npr.org/2017/04/07/522857511/adam-galinksy-what-drives-us-to-speak-up

item.title: James Hansen: What Makes A Scientist Take A Stand?
item.description: April 7, 2017 - When James Hansen spoke up about climate change in the 1980s, he risked the loss of his job and reputation. But, he says, it was worth it — because he could not be silent about something so important.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 7, 2017 - When James Hansen spoke up about climate change in the 1980s, he risked the loss of his job and reputation. But, he says, it was worth it — because he could not be silent about something so important. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/07/522856713/james-hansen-what-makes-a-scientist-take-a-stand

item.title: Bison Or Brian? From A Calorie Perspective, Cannibalism Didn't Pay For Paleo Humans
item.description: April 6, 2017 - Archaeological records show ancient humans sometimes ate each other. A new study suggests that hunting and eating other humans cost too much effort to be a regular thing. So why'd they do it?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 6, 2017 - Archaeological records show ancient humans sometimes ate each other. A new study suggests that hunting and eating other humans cost too much effort to be a regular thing. So why'd they do it? http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/06/522880018/what-s-the-dietary-value-of-a-human

item.title: In Giant Virus Genes, Hints About Their Mysterious Origin
item.description: April 6, 2017 - They're the Godzillas of the virus world, pushing the limit of what is considered alive. Researchers are trying to figure out where they came from. (And no, they aren't known to make people sick.)
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 6, 2017 - They're the Godzillas of the virus world, pushing the limit of what is considered alive. Researchers are trying to figure out where they came from. (And no, they aren't known to make people sick.) http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/06/522478901/in-giant-virus-genes-hints-about-their-mysterious-origin

item.title: How Flawed Science Is Undermining Good Medicine
item.description: April 6, 2017 - U.S. taxpayers pay $30 billion a year to fund biomedical research aimed at finding better treatments. But competition for scarce funding and tenure may be prompting some scientists to cut corners.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 6, 2017 - U.S. taxpayers pay $30 billion a year to fund biomedical research aimed at finding better treatments. But competition for scarce funding and tenure may be prompting some scientists to cut corners. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/06/522262881/how-flawed-science-is-undermining-good-medicine

item.title: Ex-Secretary Of State Advocates Causes Not Key In Modern Republican Agenda
item.description: April 5, 2017 - James Baker, who served in two Republican White Houses, is writing about causes that don't figure prominently in the modern Republican agenda. He's advocating a global ban on the sale of ivory.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 5, 2017 - James Baker, who served in two Republican White Houses, is writing about causes that don't figure prominently in the modern Republican agenda. He's advocating a global ban on the sale of ivory. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/05/522756860/ex-secretary-of-state-advocates-causes-not-key-in-modern-republican-agenda

item.title: NASA's Cassini Begins Its Final Mission Before Self-Destruction
item.description: April 5, 2017 - NASA's Cassini's spacecraft will begin the final stages of its 20-year mission to Saturn before diving into the planet and ending its lengthy stretch orbiting the planet.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 5, 2017 - NASA's Cassini's spacecraft will begin the final stages of its 20-year mission to Saturn before diving into the planet and ending its lengthy stretch orbiting the planet. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/05/522756844/nasas-cassini-begins-its-final-mission-before-self-destruction

item.title: The Race To Fish Slows Down. Why That's Good For Fish, Fishermen And Diners
item.description: April 5, 2017 - Catch shares allot fishermen a portion of the catch in advance, in hopes of keeping them from racing each other to sea, sometimes in risky climes. They're controversial. They also work, a study finds.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 5, 2017 - Catch shares allot fishermen a portion of the catch in advance, in hopes of keeping them from racing each other to sea, sometimes in risky climes. They're controversial. They also work, a study finds. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/05/522731573/the-race-to-fish-slows-down-why-thats-good-for-fish-fishermen-and-diners

item.title: Experts Suspect Nerve Agent Was Used In Syrian Attack
item.description: April 5, 2017 - An attack on a rebel-held region of Syria on Tuesday has killed dozens of people. Video and eyewitness reports suggest powerful chemical weapons are responsible.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 5, 2017 - An attack on a rebel-held region of Syria on Tuesday has killed dozens of people. Video and eyewitness reports suggest powerful chemical weapons are responsible. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/04/05/522726068/experts-suspect-nerve-agent-was-used-in-syrian-attack

item.title: Do U.S. Troops Risk Brain Injury When They Fire Heavy Weapons?
item.description: April 5, 2017 - Some modern shoulder-fired weapons produce blast waves powerful enough to rattle the brain. A $30 million study aims to help the military figure out how much blast exposure, over time, is too much.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 5, 2017 - Some modern shoulder-fired weapons produce blast waves powerful enough to rattle the brain. A $30 million study aims to help the military figure out how much blast exposure, over time, is too much. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/05/522613294/do-u-s-troops-risk-brain-injury-when-they-fire-heavy-weapons

item.title: VIDEO: Badger Burying A Cow Surprises Scientists
item.description: April 4, 2017 - The researchers say it's the first time an American badger has been documented burying an animal larger than itself. It worked for five days and nights to accomplish the unexpected feat.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 4, 2017 - The researchers say it's the first time an American badger has been documented burying an animal larger than itself. It worked for five days and nights to accomplish the unexpected feat. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/04/04/522598144/video-badger-burying-a-cow-surprises-scientists

item.title: Sound Matters: Sex And Death In The Rain Forest
item.description: April 4, 2017 - Scientists eavesdropping in trees have decoded a high stakes game of hide and seek. Katydids rely on ultrasound to find mates and listen for bats, which use ultrasound to find the bugs, and eat them.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 4, 2017 - Scientists eavesdropping in trees have decoded a high stakes game of hide and seek. Katydids rely on ultrasound to find mates and listen for bats, which use ultrasound to find the bugs, and eat them. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/04/521452464/sound-matters-sex-and-death-in-the-rain-forest

item.title: Taking Shortcuts In Drug Testing Can Put Patients At Risk
item.description: April 4, 2017 - Researchers use intermediate endpoints like how a drug lowers cholesterol to get a quick sense of whether the drug might improve health. But those shortcuts often don't show true benefits and harms.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 4, 2017 - Researchers use intermediate endpoints like how a drug lowers cholesterol to get a quick sense of whether the drug might improve health. But those shortcuts often don't show true benefits and harms. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/04/522583228/taking-shortcuts-in-drug-testing-can-put-patients-at-risk

item.title: Trump Team Urges Skimpier Health Plans To Lure More People To Buy Insurance
item.description: April 4, 2017 - A rule proposed by the Trump administration would likely raise the deductibles and copays of new policies sold on the exchanges, starting next fall. Monthly premiums would likely be cheaper.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 4, 2017 - A rule proposed by the Trump administration would likely raise the deductibles and copays of new policies sold on the exchanges, starting next fall. Monthly premiums would likely be cheaper. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/04/522482563/trump-team-urges-skimpier-health-plans-to-lure-more-people-to-buy-insurance
